text: Roberto Szidon (21 September 194121 December 2011) was a Brazilian classical pianist who had an international performing and recording career, and settled in Germany.Answers.com ==Life and career== Szidon was born in Porto Alegre, Brazil in 1941. He gave his first concert at age 9 in his home town. He then studied composition with Karl Faust, and continued his pianistic studies in the United States with Ilona Kabos and Claudio Arrau. Szidon played with many renowned orchestras. In 1977 he completed a Southern Africa tour.Roberto Szidon's tour of Southern Africa He was the soloist at the premiere of Camargo Guarnieri's Piano Concerto No. 4, in Porto Alegre, on 6 September 1972.Naxos As a recording artist, Szidon was best known for his complete recording of the 10 Piano Sonatas and the Fantaisie in B minor by Alexander ScriabinArkivMusikRapid Share Index and his complete recording of the 19 Hungarian Rhapsodies and the Rhapsodie espagnole by Franz Liszt.ArkivMusik Szidon recorded a prize-winning LP in 1965 of Heitor Villa-Lobos's Rudepoêma. Other Villa-Lobos works in his discography were A fiandeira, Saudades dos selvas brasileiras, New York Skyline (1957 version), Carnaval dos crianças, A lenda do caboclo, Suite floral, Op. 97 (1949 revision),Gramophone, October 1976 and 16 Cirandas and 12 Cirandinhas.trade bit He also recorded the works of other Brazilian composers such as Ernesto Nazareth, Francisco Mignone and Chiquinha Gonzaga. Szidon also recorded Frédéric Chopin's 4 Scherzos and 4 Impromptus (Deutsche Grammophon LP 536 378), Sergei Rachmaninoff's 2nd Sonata, Sergei Prokofiev's 6th Sonata,Gramophone, November 1969 as well as Charles Ives's "Concord Sonata", Edward MacDowell's Second Concerto and Gershwin's Concerto in F.ArkivMusik He frequently performed and recorded chamber music with violinist Jenny Abel, and accompanied Thomas Quasthoff in Schumann's Dichterliebe, Liederkreis, Op. 39, and other songs.ArkivMusik He taught piano at the music academies in Hannover and Düsseldorf, where he was a professor of piano until his death. Among his most prominent students were the Italian pianist Igor Cognolatohttp://www.igorcognolato.com , the Greek pianist Erato Alakiozidou and the German pianist Tobias Koch. Szidon died in December 2011, in Düsseldorf, Germany, of a heart attack, aged 70. From August 1970 until his death, Szidon shared his life and work with his companion, pianist and composer Richard Metzler. ==References== Category:1941 births Category:2011 deaths Category:Brazilian classical pianists Category:Brazilian expatriates in Germany Category:LGBT musicians from Germany Category:LGBT musicians from Brazil Category:Brazilian people of Hungarian descent Category:20th-century classical pianists Category:20th-century German musicians
